Modulating of MoSe2 functional plane via doping-defect engineering strategy for the development of conductive and electrocatalytic mediators in Li-S batteries Mohammed A. Al-Tahan a c Yutao Dong b ⁎ Aml E. Shrshr a Xiyang Kang a Hui Guan a Yumiao Han a Zihao Cheng a Weihua Chen a Jianmin Zhang a ⁎ a College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China College of Chemistry Zhengzhou University Zhengzhou 450001 Henan China College of Chemistry, Zhengzhou University, Zhengzhou 450001, Henan, China b College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China College of Science Henan Agricultural University Zhengzhou 450002 Henan China College of Science, Henan Agricultural University, Zhengzhou 450002, Henan, China c Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Al-Azhar University, Assiut 71524, Egypt Chemistry Department Faculty of Science Al-Azhar University Assiut 71524 Egypt Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Al-Azhar University, Assiut 71524, Egypt ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Fe-MoSe2@rGO provides a promising avenue for producing a developed separator function for practical high-energy-density Li-S batteries. Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP exhibits excellent cycling stability under lean E/S ratios and high sulfur loading. The lithium polysulfide shuttle and sluggish sulfur reaction kinetics still pose significant challenges to lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. The functional plane of Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid with abundant defects has been designed and applied in Li-S batteries to develop the functional separator and multi-layer sulfur cathode. The cell with a functional separator exhibits a retention capacity of 462 mAh g−1 after the 1000th at 0.5 C and 516 mAh g−1 after the 600th at 0.3 C. Even at low electrolyte conditions (7.0 µL mgsulfur −1 and 15 µL mgsulfur −1) under high sulfur loadings (3.46 mg cm−2 and 3.73 mg cm−2), the cell still presents high reversible discharge capacities 679 and 762 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles, respectively. Further, at sulfur loadings up to 8.26 and 5.2 mg cm−2, the cells assembled with the bi-layers sulfur cathode and the tri-layers sulfur cathode give reversible capacities of 3.3 mAh cm−2 after the 100th cycle and 3.0 mAh cm−2 after the 120th cycle, respectively. This research not only demonstrates that the Fe-MoSe2@rGO functional plane is successfully designed and applied in Li-S batteries with superior electrochemical performances but also paves the novel way for developing a unique multi-layer cathode technique to enhance and advance the electrochemical behavior of Li-S cells at a high-sulfur-loading cathode under lean electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Modified separator Fe-MoSe2@rGO Multi-layers cathode Defect engineering 1 Introduction With the fast expansion of contemporary civilization and the rapid drought of fossil energy supplies, there is a growing demand for secondary batteries with high-energy-density over 400 Wh kg−1 for multiple electronic applications, including electric automobiles [1–4]. The Li-S battery has been highlighted as one of the most excellent and promising energy storage systems because of its predicted energy density of 2600 Wh kg−1 and cheap sulfur material cost [5–7]. There have been numerous obstacles to the practical implementation of Li-S batteries, including low sulfur conductivity, the well-documented shuttle effect, and the requirement for an adequate volume change (80%) of sulfur during charging and discharging operations, all of which have hampered the use of Li-S cells [8–10]. In order to overcome these constraints and enhance the battery's electrochemical performance, many solutions have been developed, such as sulfur cathode host materials [11–13], functional electrolyte additives [14], modifying functional separators/introducing interlayers [15,16], binder enhancement [17], lithium metal protection [18] or via Redox co-mediators (coRMs) [19]. The strategy of modifying functional separators for various sulfur species provides a less radical technique for modulating their dissolution/diffusion behavior. Also, the modified separators could prevent the soluble polysulfide intermediates from migrating towards the anode and thus stop the reaction with metallic lithium [20]. Different modified functional separators have been designed, including carbonaceous materials [21,22], organic materials (such as Polymer [23] or MOF-based materials [24]), and inorganic materials (such as metal oxides [25], carbides [26], sulfides [27], phosphides [28], borides [29], or nitrides [30]). However, their inadequate adsorptive and catalytic performance due to a lack of active sites remains a significant hurdle to achieving good Li-S chemistry [31]. Newly, introducing electrocatalysts has generally been regarded as a viable method for accelerating sulfur redox processes [32]. Transition metal chalcogenides (TMDs), such as molybdenum diselenide (MoSe2), are among the compounds that have sparked the curiosity of academics and researchers due to their distinctive features such as large specific surface area, high conductivity, low cost, high-throughput fabrication procedure, and excellent electrocatalytic activity derived from edge sites, selenide defects, and vacancies [33–35]. In terms of crystal structure, MoSe2 has a lamellar structure with layers of Se-Mo-Se sandwiched together [36]. Mo-Se interactions are distinguished by strong covalent bonding, whereas mild van der Waals forces represent interactions between monolayers [37]. However, the limited active sites of MoSe2 would considerably reduce their total electrocatalytic performance. In this context, constructing evenly dispersed MoSe2 nanostructures on a conductive substrate with more exposed selenium edges is an excellent technique for improving electrocatalytic performance [38]. The reduced graphene oxide (rGO) might be used as a conductive matrix for TMDs because of its superior electrical conductivity, sufficient flexibility, and extensive specific surface area [39,40]. Furthermore, metal doping into TMDs can not only improve the electronic conductivity of TMDs, but can also generate many defects, exposing more reactive sites for catalytic reactions [41]. Polysulfide transformation in the Li-S system could be improved through defect engineering, which can alter a material’s physicochemical and electronic structure to boost adsorption and catalytic properties [42]. This study develops a bifunctional electrocatalyst by modulating cation iron doping in MoSe2 (Fe-MoSe2), which is then in situ hybridized with conductive rGO nanosheets via a one-step hydrothermal process. Adsorption of polysulfide anions on MoSe2 is prevented by the constrained active sites of MoSe2 throughout the recycling process. The introduction of iron could expose more active selenium edge sites of MoSe2, which can selectively adsorb more lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) to minimize the shuttle effect. Besides, the conductive feature of rGO could boost the cell’s electrical conductivity and promote polysulfides’ adsorption through chemical bonding with the functional group of rGO. Therefore, the Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid as a functional plane has the attractive benefits of high conductivity and more effective LiPSs adsorption sites. The cell with Fe-MoSe2@rGO coated on the separator contributes capacity retention of 462 mAh g−1 after the 1000th cycle at 0.5 C, and 516 mAh g−1 after the 600th cycle at 0.3 C, resulting from defect engineering. The high discharge capacity could be attained even under low electrolyte conditions (7.0 and 15 µL mgsulfur −1) and high sulfur loading (3.46 and 3.73 mg cm−2). Additionally, the Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid exhibits superior conductivity, anti-self discharge behavior, and improved LiPSs adsorption sites. The Li-S Cells assembled with the bi-layer sulfur cathode and the tri-layer sulfur cathode exhibit extraordinary electrochemical performances with reversible discharge capacities of 3.3 mAh cm−2 at the sulfur loading 8.26 mg cm−2 after the 100th cycle and 3.0 mAh cm−2 at the sulfur loading 5.2 mg cm−2 after the 120th cycle, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Fe-doped MoSe2@rGO The Fe-doped MoSe2@rGO was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. To begin, 0.32 g of Se powder was put in a 20 mL N2H4 solution and stirred for 24 h. At the same time, 0.6 g of CTAB was dispersed into 30 mL of GO solution (2.0 mg mL−1) with continuous stirring for 24 h. 2.0 mmol of a mixture of Na2MoO4 2H2O and Fe(NO3)3.9H2O (molar ratio = 96:4) was dissolved in 20 mL DI-water. Next, the Mo/Fe-ions solution was added to the CTAB-GO solution and stirred for an additional 6.0 h to guarantee that the Na2MoO4 was adsorbed onto the GO surface. After that, drop by drop, the Se-N2H4 solution was added to the abovementioned solution. The mixture was then heated for 12 h at 200 °C in a 100-mL PTFE-lined autoclave. The black precipitate was recovered by centrifugation after cooling to ambient temperature, washed (with deionized water and pure ethanol), and dried in a vacuum at 60 °C. Except for no addition of Fe(NO3)3⋅9H2O, MoSe2@rGO was synthesized using the same procedure. 2.2 Preparation of sulfur cathode At 155 °C in an Ar environment, a super P and sulfur (in a mass ratio of 20:80) were heated for 10 h to form the S/SP composite. According to the TGA calculation, the ultimate sulfur level of the S/SP composite is around 80 wt% (Fig. S1). In order to create the slurry, the polyvinylidene fluoride binder (PVDF) and S/SP composite were mixed (mass ratio of 10:90) and submerged in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). A vacuum-oven drier was used to dry the slurry for 12 h at 50 °C over a carbon-coated Al foil. The electrode was sliced into a 14-mm circular with an average sulfur mass loading between 1.2 and 1.5 mg cm−2. 2.3 Multi-layers sulfur cathode preparation After combining S/SP composite and PVDF in a mass ratio of 90:10, the mixture was put in NMP to form a slurry. The slurry was spread over a carbon-coated Al foil to obtain the cathode’s sulfur layer (S-layer), which was dried for 12 h at 50 °C in a vacuum-oven drier. Then, a thin layer of Fe-MoSe2@rGO (FMC-layer) was coated on the sulfur layer (S-layer) and dried again at 50 °C to give a cathode with two different layers (S-layer/FMC-layer). Here, the FMC-layer was prepared via the mixing Fe-MoSe2@rGO, super P, and PVDF in NMP in a mass ratio of 7:2:1. Finally, the sulfur bi-layers cathode was achieved by adding one FMC-layer between two layers of S-layer. The shape of the bi-layer sulfur cathode is FMC-layer sandwiched between two S-layer (S-layer/FMC-layer/S-layer). Similarly, the tri-layers sulfur cathode was prepared by two FMC-layers between three S-layers. So, the tri-layers sulfur cathode form was as S-layer/FMC-layer/S-layer/FMC-layer/S-layer. The multi-layer sulfur cathode was sliced into a 14 mm diameter circular. The average mass loading of Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid in the thin layer of the FMC-layer is around 0.5 mg cm−2. The average mass of sulfur loading in the S-layer was calculated for each layer separately, and then the final sulfur mass of the cathode as a whole was obtained by adding each S-layer mass, excluding the mass of the total FMC-layer. 2.4 Preparation of Fe-MoSe2@rGO-coated separator To make a paste, we mixed Fe-MoSe2@rGO, PVDF, and super P in NMP at a mass ratio of 7:1:2. The Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP was fabricated after the paste had been applied on the separator’s side (Celgard 2400) and heated under vacuum at 50 °C. Circular disks with a diameter of 19 mm had an average mass loading of 0.22 mg cm−2 Fe-MoSe2@rGO. Compared to Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP, the MoSe2@rGO-PP was made in the same way. 2.5 Materials characterization A Panalytical X’Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer was used to record the diffraction pattern. Field-emission scanning microscopy was used to capture SEM pictures (FESEM, Zeiss Auriga 500). TEM, HRTEM, and elemental mappings images were analyzed on an FEI TECNAIG2F20-S-TWIN microscope operated at 200 kV. Sulfur content in related composites was detected by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Simultaneous Thermal Analyzer, 409 PC). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi) with Al K monochromatic radiation was used to examine the chemical interaction between Fe-MoSe2@rGO and Li2S6. A LabRAM HR Evolution (HORIBA) Raman system with a laser power of 5 mW and wavelength of 532 nm was used to acquire the Raman spectra. An N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm on a Micromeritics ASAP 2420-4MP apparatus was recorded to assess the surface area and pore-size distribution. The UV–visible spectra for lithium polysulfide adsorption experiments were achieved by Perkin Elmer Lamda 25 UV/Vis Spectrophotometer. 2.6 Electrochemical measurements C.R.2032 coin-type cells were produced utilizing either the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP, MoSe2@rGO-PP, or PP (Celgard 2400) as a separator and lithium metal as the counter electrodes. The Li-S cell was entirely built in an argon-filled glove box. The electrolyte included 1 M LiTFSI in a 1:1 (volume ratio) combination of DOL (1,3-dioxolane) and DME (dimethoxyethane), with a 5.0% LiNO3 additive. Recordings of the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and the CV were made using an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E). The CV voltage ranges from 1.7 to 2.8 V, while the EIS frequency ranges from 0.01 to 105 Hz. In order to conduct galvanostatic charge/discharge cycles in the range of 1.7–2.8 V (vs. Li+/Li), a LAND CT2001A battery tester was employed. The Randles-Sevcik equation can elucidate the lithium diffusion process [43]. I p = ( 2.69 × 10 5 ) n 0.5 A D 0.5 C v 0.5 Here I p stands for peak current, n for the number of charge transfers, A for electrode area (cm2), D and C for diffusion coefficient (cm2 s−1), and Li+ concentration (mol mL−1), respectively, and v for scan rate (V s−1). Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was used to study the electrochemical stability of various separators in a cell made up of Li-foil/separator immersed in electrolyte/stainless steel. The cell was scanned at 5 mV s−1 in a voltage range of 0.0–6.0 V. EIS analysis was used to determine the ionic conductivity ( σ ) of the separators, with a frequency range of 105–10−2 Hz and an amplitude of 5 mV. A distinct, independently immersed electrolyte separator between two stainless steel plates in a CR2032 coin cell was used to construct the cell. In order to calculate the ionic conductivity, the following equation was used. σ = L R × A Here, R, L, and A are the bulk resistance, thickness, and separator area, respectively. 2.7 Adsorption experiment of LiPSs To make Li2S6 solution, a combination of elemental sulfur and Li2S (molar ratio 5:1) was dissolved in a homogenous solvent made up of DME and DOL (1:1) and maintained stirring for 48 h at 50 °C in an argon-filled glove box. 20 mg of the synthesized materials were added to a 3.0 mL Li2S6 (3.0 mmol) solution in the adsorption test. When the supernatant had been settling for 8.0 h, it was taken for digital photography. After adsorption, the clear supernatant solution was assembled individually (∼2 mL) for UV-vis testing. The Fe-MoSe2@rGO residue was allowed to dry in an argon-filled glove box before being examined for XPS. 2.8 Symmetric cells assembly The Li2S6 electrolyte was prepared by mixing Li2S and sulfur powder (molar ratio of 1:5), then the mix was dissolved into a commercial electrolyte and kept stirring in an Ar-filled glove box at 50 °C for 48 h. Fe-MoSe2@rGO or MoSe2@rGO and PVDF were mixed in an 80:20 mass ratio to create the electrode for symmetric cells. A slurry was formed by immersing the combination in NMP solution and then painting it onto an Al foil and drying it at 50 °C. A 14 mm disk was used as the electrodes. Celgard 2400 was applied as a separator, and 50 µL of Li2S6 (0.2 M) was utilized as an electrolyte in a standard 2032-coin cell. Both the working and counter electrodes were made of the same material. The catalytic effect of various materials (Fe-MoSe2@rGO or MoSe2@rGO) as modified separators was performed via a symmetric cell built by the Al-foil/separator/Al-foil cell with Li2S6 electrolyte. CV evaluations of the symmetrical cells were performed on an electrochemical workstation using voltages of −1.0–1.0 V and scan rate of 0.01 V s−1. 2.9 Li2S nucleation/dissolution experiments Dissolving Li2S and S (1:7, molar ratio) in a DME/DOL (vol/vol 1:1) solution with 1 M LiTFSI and 1.0% LiNO3 resulted in a solution of Li2S8 (0.2 M). Celgard 2400 was utilized as a separator and lithium foil as a counter electrode in this project. The working electrode is the same as the symmetric cell’s electrode. 25 µL volume of 0.2 M Li2S8 solution was used as the catholyte, and the same volume of an electrolyte lacking Li2S8 was used as the anolyte. Li2S nucleation was carried out by discharging the cells at 0.1 mA until the potential was decreased to 2.11 V, and then maintaining it at 2.09 V under a holding time of 5000 s to complete the process. In Li2S dissolving experiments, the batteries were first discharged at a current of 0.1 mA until the voltage dropped to 1.7 V, and then they were charged potentiostatically at 2.4 V. 2.10 First-principles calculations First-principles calculations were performed using density-functional theory (DFT) using the VASP code [44–46]. The projector augmented wave method (PAW) [47] described the electronic-ion interaction. The energy cut-off plane waves used as the basis of wave function were set to 450 eV. The electron exchange–correlation function was treated using a generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the form proposed by Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) [48]. The conjugate gradient (CG) algorithm is employed to optimize both atomic positions and lattice vectors. The convergence precision for energy and force is set to 10−5 eV and 0.1 eV Å−1, respectively. A vacuum region larger than 15 Å was adopted to eliminate the interaction of two adjacent images. The Brillouin zone (BZ) integration was sampled by using a single G (0, 0, 0) k-point for 5 × 5 super cell of MoSe2. The van der Waals interaction was included using the DFT-D3 method of Grimme [47]. The spin-polarized total energy calculations were carried out for all optimized structures. The binding energy (E b) was defined as E b = E Surf + E Li2S x − E total, where E surf is the energy of the optimized bare surface, E Li2S x is the energy of the optimized polysulfides, and E total is the energy of the complete adsorption system. The higher binding energy renders enhanced stability for adsorbed particles. 3 Results and discussion The fabrication processes for the MoSe2@rGO and Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrids are depicted in Fig. 1 (a). As the surfactant CTAB is added to the solution of GO, the surface charge of GO has been tuned via the interaction between the GO basal plane and the long-chain alkyl group of the surfactant. Then, the MoO4 2− anion is added to the solution of GO-CTAB and directly attracted by the positively charged hydrophobic tail of CTAB [49]. Finally, the Se-N2H4 and Fe3+ ions are added to the solution of MoO4 2− anions adsorbed on a CTAB-modified GO surface and hydrothermally treated at 200 °C, resulting in MoSe2@rGO decorated by Iron (Fe-MoSe2@rGO). SEM images have been performed to detect the morphology of the as-synthesized pure MoSe2 and Fe-MoSe2@rGO. The highly-dense nanosheets MoSe2 are synthesized, as shown in Fig. 1(b). MoSe2 is comprised of exceptionally tiny sheets with slight edge length, as noticed from the high magnification SEM image (Fig. S2). The SEM image of Fe-MoSe2@rGO is revealed in Fig. 1(c). The surface of the graphene nanosheets was wholly coated by very thin and wrinkled MoSe2 nanosheets, resulting in a porous honeycomb-like hierarchical structure. The absence of individual MoSe2 nanosheets shows that a highly ordered MoSe2@rGO superstructure can be obtained in the presence of CTAB via a hydrothermal method. The ultrathin structure of the Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanosheets with apparent waves and corrugations has been revealed by the TEM images (Fig. 1d and Fig. S3). Furthermore, the HRTEM image of Fe-MoSe2@rGO shows the presence of rich defects (Fig. 1e), which resulted in a quasi-periodic arrangement of the atoms in the core plane, causing the crystal ends to rotate dramatically with each other. The quasi-periodic atomic configuration in the basal planes may generate and develop great active sites, promoting the electrochemical performance of Li-S cells [50]. The HR-TEM picture also shows that the ultrathin MoSe2 nanosheets comprise a few layers with a 0.68 nm interplanar gap corresponding to the (002) plane. The spacing is higher than that of pure bulk MoSe2 (0.646 nm), which is consistent with XRD experiments [51]. As shown in Fig. S4, the matching fast Fourier transform (FFT) patterns and inverse FFT patterns of the specified defect located in the HR-TEM picture have been performed. The poorer selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern with a less defined crystal structure is reported, which are defect area characteristics [52]. The high angle annular dark field-STEM (HAADF-STEM) image and corresponding EDS elemental mapping images reveal uniform distributions of Mo, Se, C, and Fe elements for the Fe-MoSe2@rGO, establishing the flourishing Fe-doping on MoSe2@rGO (Fig. 1f and g). The XRD patterns of MoSe2, MoSe2@rGO, and Fe-MoSe2@rGO are shown in Fig. 2 (a). The broad peaks at about 32.3° and 55.4°, respectively, describe the crystal planes of MoSe2 of (100) and (110), which match the JCPDS card no (29-0914) [53]. The weak peak corresponding to the (002) plane reveals that the interlayer spacing of MoSe2 is changed [51]. The Raman spectra of MoSe2, MoSe2@rGO, and Fe-MoSe2@rGO have depicted in Fig. 2(b). The Raman peaks at around 232 and 280 cm−1 can be assigned to the typical out-of-plane A1g and in-plane E1 2g vibration modes in hexagonal MoSe2 [54]. For these materials, the intensity of E1 2g mode is lower than that of A1g mode, markers of edge-rich features in MoSe2 nanosheets [55]. As shown in Fig. 2(c), the D– and G– bands intensities ratios (I D/I G) for GO, rGO, MoSe2@rGO, and Fe-MoSe2@rGO reflect the structural defect capacities in rGO or GO. The I D/I G of rGO in the Fe-MoSe2@rGO is 1.29, which is greater than in the GO (0.98), rGO (1.03), and MoSe2@rGO (1.17), indicating that the rGO has more comfy bonds and defects following the addition of Fe-MoSe2. At a relative pressure of P/P 0 greater than 0.5, the N2 isotherms of MoSe2@rGO and Fe-MoSe2@rGO display type IV feature with a prominent capillary condensation hysteresis loop (Fig. S5a and b), suggesting that the MoSe2@rGO and Fe-MoSe2@rGO have a mesoporous structure with pores of roughly 4.0 nm (Fig. S5c and d). MoSe2@rGO and Fe-MoSe2@rGO have Braun-Emmet-Teller (BET) surfaces of 21.3 and 32.9 m2 g−1, respectively. The nanohybrids’ very modest surface area may be due to the close contact between the rGO and MoSe2 sheets [56]. Polysulfide adsorption tests have been carried out to verify the interaction of the Fe-MoSe2@rGO with the Li2S6 solution (Fig. 2d). A transition from brilliant yellow to virtually transparent in the Li2S6 solution containing Fe-MoSe2@rGO after 8.0 h indicates a high attraction of Fe-MoSe2@rGO for polysulfide ions. Also, as shown in the UV-vis adsorption spectra (Fig. S6), the absorption peak of Fe-MoSe2@rGO is more down than MoSe2@rGO and blank solution, indicating that Fe-MoSe2@rGO has a better affinity and improves the adsorption capacity of LiPSs resulting from the enriched surface defects induced by Fe doping. Moreover, XPS has proven that Fe-MoSe2@rGO and polysulfides have a chemical interaction, as shown by the results. The great purity of the nanohybrid can be seen in the wide-scan XPS spectrum (Fig. S7), which offers distinct peaks for Mo, Se, C, Fe, and O. Likewise, the atomic percentages of Mo, Se, C, Fe, and O in the Fe-MoSe2@rGO are 9.31%, 13.20%, 70.63%, 0.38%, and 6.49%, respectively, confirming that Mo:Fe ratio is very near to 96:4 (authenticating that the percentage of Fe dopant is 4.0%). The high-resolution Mo 3d XPS spectrum before and after adsorption with Li2S6 has been shown in Fig. 2(e). Before adsorption, the two peaks located at 227.9 and 231.0 eV can be assigned to the Mo4+ 3d 5/2 and Mo4+ 3d 3/2 , respectively, which are in agreement with Mo-Se structures [57]. The peaks placed at 231.5 and 233.2 eV show the presence of Mo6+ due to the MoO4 2− or the appearance of MoO3 on the surface of Mo [58]. While the peak at 228.5 eV is assumably associated with the Se 3 s [59]. Meanwhile, the high-resolution Se 3d XPS spectrum before contact with the Li2S6 solution shows two peaks at around 53.2 and 54.1 eV are attributed to the Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 3/2 binding energies of MoSe2, respectively (Fig. 2f) [60,61]. Nevertheless, after being adsorbed by Li2S6, the distinctive peaks of Mo 3d and Se 3d have been moved to higher binding energies. This is due to the high electrophilic ability of Li2S6, which causes electron clouds around Mo and Se to be drawn to sulfur ligands during the adsorption process. Consequently, the Mo 3d and Se 3d XPS characteristic peaks move to higher binding energies [62–64]. In addition, the XPS spectra of Fe 2p in Fe-MoSe2@rGO before and after adsorption with the Li2S6 solution have been performed, as shown in Fig. 2(g). Before contact with the Li2S6 solution, the Fe 2p 3/2 core level is divided into two peaks at 707.0 and 709.5 eV, corresponding to Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively. Similarly, the Fe 2p 1/2 core level includes two peaks at 720.3 and 725.1 eV related to Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively [13,65]. The Fe 2p peak shifts to higher binding energy after adsorption with Li2S6, establishing the powerful interaction between Li2S6 and Fe-MoSe2@rGO. The high-resolution S 2p spectra likewise deliver further proof of a superior adsorption ability of Fe-MoSe2@rGO (Fig. 2h). The terminal (ST −1) at 159.9 eV and the bridging (SB 0) sulfur peaks at 161.2 eV are elucidated to Li2S6 adsorbed in Fe-MoSe2@rGO. The thiosulfate peak at 165.9 eV derives from the surface redox reaction between Fe-MoSe2@rGO and Li2S6. The peak at 168.0 eV is due to the presence of the polythionate complex originating from the chemical interaction among sulfur species and Fe-MoSe2@rGO [66]. The C 1s spectrum exhibits two prominent peaks at 283.9 and 285.2 eV, which correspond to CC and CO bonds, respectively (Fig. 2i) [67]. The strong chemical at the interface between MoSe2 and graphene nanosheets is indicated by the peak at 282.5 eV, which is attributable to the development of C–Mo bond [49]. The symmetric cell technique is used to examine the impact of Fe doping on polysulfide redox reactions. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) of symmetric cells is assembled with two identical Fe-MoSe2@rGO or MoSe2@rGO electrodes in an electrolyte containing 0.2 mol L−1 Li2S6 for electrochemical testing. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the CV curves of symmetric cells with Fe-MoSe2@rGO electrodes present higher currents than those with MoSe2@rGO electrodes. The results indicate that Fe doping has more activity and reversibility toward polysulfide transformation. Further, the first five cycles of the Fe-MoSe2@rGO electrode in the CV of the symmetric cell have been achieved in Fig. S8. The closely excellent superimposition of the peaks implies good stability of the Fe-MoSe2@rGO electrode [68]. In addition, the Fe-MoSe2@rGO electrode displays pronounced redox peaks with increasing scan rates up to 30 mV s−1 (Fig. 3b), revealing an ultrafast catalytic conversion of soluble LiPSs [69]. Further, potentiostatic experiments have been performed to comprehend the improved electrochemical performance. As noticed in Fig. 3(c and d), the Fe-MoSe2@rGO provides earlier and higher Li2S nucleation/dissolution peaks than MoSe2@rGO, exhibiting the significant enhancement in Li2S formation/dissolution kinetics on Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid. Fig. 4 (a) offers the Li-S battery configuration assembled with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP as a modified separator. The Fe-MoSe2@rGO could physically adsorb and chemically interact with the polysulfide in the cathode region to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S cells. The Fe-MoSe2@rGO is uniformly built on a separator with a coating thickness of ∼22 µm (Fig. 4b), and the areal loading is ∼0.22 mg cm−2. Bending/folding experiments are carried out to investigate the mechanical characteristics of as-formed separators. As seen in the digital pictures in Fig. 4(c), Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP has good mechanical resilience, allowing for the exhibition of its multi-functionality. The initial five cycles of the cell’s CV curves with the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP are shown in Fig. 5 (a). During the charging-discharging process, sulfur oxidation and reduction reach two distinct maxima. The open-ring reaction of sulfur (S8) to lithium polysulfides (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) and the deposition reaction of insoluble Li2S from lithium polysulfides are ascribed to the two reduction peaks at 2.32 and 2.03 V, respectively [70]. In the anodic scan, two distinct peaks at 2.32 and 2.41 V are also observed, derived from the reverse transformation (i.e., Li2S2/Li2S to Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8 and then to S8) [71]. In addition, it is noticed that in the subsequent sweeps up to the 5th cycle, the reduction peaks are shifted to higher potential and the oxidation peaks are moved to lower potential (as shown in Fig. 5a). On the other hand, there is an extreme polarization phenomenon in the CV curves of cells containing the MoSe2@rGO-PP (Fig. 5b) and PP (Fig. S9), which may be explained by the functional performances of distinct separators. Therefore, the outstanding reversibility of the redox reaction can be achieved under the catalysis of Fe-MoSe2@rGO. Moreover, the CV profiles have been conducted under different scan rates to calculate the lithium-ion diffusion coefficient (D Li +), as shown in Fig. S10(a and b). Based on the Randles-Sevcik equation (as documented in the Experimental section), the plotting of redox peak currents (I p) of the cells with different separators against the scan rate’s square root (ν0.5) is shown in Fig. S10(c and d), and a linear relationship is given. Thus, the curve slope could describe the lithium-ion diffusion rate. The cell with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP separator shows a higher Li+ diffusion rate (confirmed from the higher redox peak slope in Table S1) than pristine PP due to high electrolyte wettability, leading to rapid redox kinetics. Fig. 5(c) depicts the CV profiles of symmetric cells constructed by Al-foil/separator/Al-foil cell using Li2S6 (0.2 mol L−1) electrolyte. The more elevated redox current peaks are achieved by the CV profile of Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP, confirming the improvement of the catalytic activity of LiPSs conversion by the Fe doping. Further, the cell assembled with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP displays higher ionic conductivity than the cell with MoSe2@rGO-PP and PP, as recorded in Fig. 5(d). This is due to the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP’s high electrolyte attraction and evenly pore dispersion, resulting in rapid Li+ transportation [72]. The electrochemical stability of various separators has been investigated using LSV (Fig. S11). Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP and MoSe2@rGO-PP cells exhibit negligible oxidation current under 4.80 V (vs. Li/Li+), demonstrating good electrochemical stability and resistance to electrochemical oxidation in these cells. Accordingly, Li-S batteries could benefit from using the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP as a modified separator. Fig. 6 (a) exhibits the cycling performance of the cells with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP, MoSe2@rGO-PP, or PP separators at 0.3 C (1.0 C = 1673 mA g−1). The cell with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP separator shows a considerable high initial capacity of 1488.4 mAh g−1 and holds an excellent reversible capacity of 516.0 mAh g−1 after the 600th cycle. At the start of cycling, the permanent capacity loss can be attributed to the creation of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) [73,74]. By contrast, the cell with the MoSe2@rGO-PP separator offers a high initial capacity of 1293.9 mAh g−1, but the capacity decays to 342.3.2 mAh g−1 after the 300th cycle. Meanwhile, the cell with Celgard (PP) delivers an initial capacity of 1122.2 mAh g−1 and fastly decreases to 254.3 mAh g−1 after the 200th cycle. Fig. 6(b) shows the 1st galvanostatic discharge/charge profiles of the cells. The battery with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP provides a voltage hysteresis between the charge and discharge plateau of ∼203 mV, which is lower than that of the batteries with MoSe2@rGO-PP (∼243 mV) or PP (∼256 mV). Furthermore, as demonstrated in Fig. 6(c), the cell with the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP separator has outstanding rate performance from 0.1 to 2 C. At 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 C, the cell yields consistent discharge specific capacities of 1660, 1152, 839, 612, and 492 mAh g−1, respectively. When the current density recovers to 0.2 C, the cell provides capacity at 700 mAh g−1 even after 200 cycles, confirming the good cyclic reversibility of the system. The Nyquist plots of different cells based on pristine Celgard and modified separators have been exhibited in Fig. 6(d). Here, R s symbolizes the resistance of the electrolyte, and Zw represents the Warburg element. The charge-transfer resistance (R ct) is connected to the semicircle at high-frequencies, whereas the ion diffusivity is related to the sloping line at low-frequencies [27]. It is obvious that the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP battery has the least R ct and R s (Table S2), indicating that the shuttling effect of LiPSs has been inhibited. Additionally, after the 100th cycle at 0.1 C with high sulfur loading of 4.8 and 5.3 mg cm−2, the cell using Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP still possesses a retention capacity of 487 and 436 mAh g−1, respectively (Fig. S12). Fig. 6(e) reveals the long-term cycling performance of the cells with various separators. With capacity retention of 462 mAh g−1 after the 1000th cycle, the cell with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP gives more power than cells with MoSe2@rGO-PP (which only retain 192 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles) or PP (109 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles). Also, the cell containing Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP has a retention capacity of 412 and 360 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at high currents of 2.0 and 5.0 C, respectively (Fig. S13). Based on these findings, the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP is an exceptional separator for Li-S batteries which compete with other modified separators/interlayers (Table S3). The diffusion and reactions of LiPSs at the Li anode cause the high self-discharge rate of Li-S batteries. Because the LiPSs species are soluble in ether-based electrolytes, after reducing sulfur, the electrolytes serve as a “catholyte”. A mixture of insoluble Li2S2/Li2S is formed when the diffusing polysulfides touch the Li-metal anode during the resting interval. Passivation of the Li metal surface is caused by these combinations precipitating, resulting in active material loss and shortened cycle life [75]. The self-discharge behavior of Li-S cell with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP modified separator has been achieved for understanding the catalytic effect of Fe-MoSe2@rGO during the rest period. The discharge–charge potential profiles with Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP separator are recorded against the time at 0.4 C in Fig. 7 (a). As shown in Fig. 7(b), the cell runs 50 cycles at 0.4 C. Along with these cycles, the cell is rested three times; each rest time is 24 h. The first rest time is between the 10th and 11th cycle (rest time I), the second rest time between the 20th and 21st cycle (rest time II), and the third rest time between the 30th and 31st cycle (rest time III). Then the cell is resumed up to the 50th cycle without any rest time. After the rest times I, II, and III, the capacity retention rates are 97.7%, 101.6%, and 98.5%, respectively (Fig. 7c–e). It has been shown that using the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP separators, it is possible to prevent polysulfides from transferring to the Li anode during the rest period, resulting in an excellent anti-self discharge behavior. As a result of LiPSs dissolving in the electrolyte, sulfur usage will decrease at high E/S ratios [76]. Hence, the construction of Li-S batteries under lean electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratios is essential for achieving the outstanding electrochemical performance of the improved separator in practical applications. When the E/S ratio decreases, the electrolyte viscosity rises. The high viscosity is harmful to the electrochemical performance in the discharge/charge process [77], so the cycling characterization is vital to the Li-S cell at lean electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratios. Fig. 7(f) shows the cycle performance of the Fe-MoSe2@rGO-PP cell with high sulfur loading and low E/S ratios. With sulfur loadings of 3.46 and 3.73 mg cm−2, the reversible discharge capacity is 679 and 762 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles for E/S ratios of 7.0 and 15 µL mg−1, respectively. On top of all that, a cell with an E/S ratio of 12 µL mg−1 and 3.2 mg cm−2 sulfur loading is examined for its rate performance (0.1 to 2.0 C) (Fig. 7g). At current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 C, the cell can discharge 1069, 848, 569, 405, and 245 mAh g−1, respectively. After 80 cycles, the cell’s capacity is 900 mAh g−1 when the current density is reset to 0.1 C, guaranteeing excellent cyclic reversibility. One the majority of laboratory-scale indicators of success have been based on batteries with sulfur loadings less than 2.0 mg cm−2, which is much below the level required for practical applications. In order to bridge the gap between laboratory-scale research and industry, high-sulfur-loading experiments are essential [78]. It has become widely accepted that cell parameter such as sulfur loading, sulfur weight percentage in the cathode, and the electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio significantly impact specific energy and energy density in the context of the entire device [79]. To pave the way for developing high electrochemical behavior of Li-S batteries at a high-sulfur-loading cathode, the cell assembled with a unique multi-layer cathode technique (as a novel strategy) has been introduced to further study the electrocatalytic effect of Fe-MoSe2@rGO. The preparation method of the multi-layers cathode has been illustrated in Fig. 8 (a). The bi-layers cathode consists of two thick layers of S-layer interspersed with a thin FMC-layer (more details in the experimental section). Also, the tri-layers cathode consists of three layers of S-layer incorporated with two thin layers of FMC-layer. The cross-sectional SEM image confirmed that the tri-layers cathode had been successfully prepared with a thick S-layer and a thin FMC-layer (Fig. S14). A bi-layers sulfur cathode cell’s design and cycling performance are shown in Fig. 8(b–d). Using a high sulfur loading of 3.82 mg cm−2 and a ratio of E/S of 15 µL mg−1, the cell has a high retention capacity of 671 mAh g−1 after the 140th cycle (Fig. 8c). The cell’s areal capacity at a high loading of 8.26 mg cm−2 still holds 3.3 mAh cm−2 after the 100th cycle under an E/S ratio of 15 µL mg−1 (Fig. 8d). The enhanced wetting of the S cathode by the electrolyte during the early cycles is responsible for the rise in capacity during long cycles [80]. In addition, as shown in Fig. 8(e), the electrochemical performance of a cell constructed with tri-layer sulfur cathodes has been tested. After the 120th cycle, the cell has a high areal capacity of 3.0 mAh cm−2 with a sulfur loading of 5.2 mg cm−2 and an E/S ratio of 15 µL mg−1 (Fig. 8f). Further, a cell with the tri-layers cathodes under an E/S ratio of 7 µL mg−1 and 5.46 mg cm−2 sulfur loading is examined for its rate performance (0.05 to 0.5 C) (Fig. 8g). At current densities of 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, and 0.5 C, the cell can discharge 6.9, 3.1, 2.4, and 1.6 mAh cm−2, respectively. The cell’s capacity is 3.1 mAh cm−2 when the current density is reset to 0.1 C and retains 2.9 mAh cm−2 after 70 cycles, guaranteeing excellent cyclic reversibility. Also, the cell with a cathode prepared by directly mixing the Fe-MoSe2@rGO (30 wt%) with sulfur/carbon composite (70 wt%) has been achieved to present the benefits of the multi-layers cathode. As displayed in Fig. S15, the Li-S cell supplies an areal capacity of 1.37 mAh cm−2 with a sulfur loading of 2.5 mg cm−2 and an E/S ratio of 40 µL mg−1 after the 50th cycle under a current density of 0.1 C. It indicates that the novel strategy to build a unique multi-layers cathode technique for developing advanced Li-S batteries with high-sulfur-loading and lean E/S ratio has proved to be a new feasible and practical tactic. Furthermore, a first-principles calculation is performed inside DFT to demonstrate the interaction between lithium sulfide varieties and Fe-MoSe2@rGO. The atomic structures of Fe-MoSe2-Li2S x (x = 4, 6, 8) and MoSe2-Li2S x , are shown in Fig. 9 (a and b), respectively. The adsorption energies of pure MoSe2 for polysulfide compounds (Li2S x ) are 1.08, 0.89, and 0.97 eV, respectively, according to the data (Fig. 9c). While, the adsorption energies of Fe-MoSe2 for polysulfide compounds (Li2S x ) are 1.22, 1.05, and 1.21 eV, respectively (Fig. 9d), which is higher than the undoped pure surface of MoSe2@rGO. As a result, the Fe-MoSe2@rGO has a more critical capacity to inhibit the shuttle effect of polysulfides. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Fe-doping MoSe2 has in-situ been formed on reduced oxygen graphene nanosheet to obtain Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrids via a hydrothermal reaction technique. The introduction of the iron atom into MoSe2 would result in more metal defects and expose more selenium edge sites, which has been verified on TEM images, XRD patterns, and Raman spectra. The functional plane, which is made from the Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid with plenty of defects, has been designed and applied in Li-S batteries to develop the functional separator and the multi-layer sulfur cathode. The cell with the Fe-MoSe2@rGO decorated functional separator exhibits superior anti-self discharge behavior and excellent electrocatalytic ability, which results in the retention capacity of 462 mAh g−1 after the 1000th at 0.5 C, and 516 mAh g−1 after the 600th at 0.3 C. Even at low electrolyte conditions and high sulfur loadings, 7.0 µL mgsulfur −1 at 3.46 mg cm−2, 15 µL mgsulfur −1 at 3.73 mg cm−2, it can still present high reversible discharge capacities 679 and 762 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles, respectively. Although their sulfur loadings are up to 8.26 and 5.2 mg cm−2, the Li-S Cells assembled with the bi-layer sulfur cathode and the tri-layer sulfur cathode give good electrochemical performances with reversible discharge capacities of 3.3 mAh cm−2 after the 100th cycle and 3.0 mAh cm−2 after the 120th cycle, respectively. This study not only proves that the Fe-MoSe2@rGO functional plane is successfully designed and applied in Li-S batteries with excellent electrochemical performances but also puts forward a novel strategy to construct a unique multi-layer sulfur cathode for developing advanced Li-S batteries with high-sulfur-loading and lean E/S ratio. coredata.dc:description: The lithium polysulfide shuttle and sluggish sulfur reaction kinetics still pose significant challenges to lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries. The functional plane of Fe-MoSe2@rGO nanohybrid with abundant defects has been designed and applied in Li-S batteries to develop the functional separator and multi-layer sulfur cathode. The cell with a functional separator exhibits a retention capacity of 462 mAh g−1 after the 1000th at 0.5 C and 516 mAh g−1 after the 600th at 0.3 C. Even at low electrolyte conditions (7.0 µL mgsulfur −1 and 15 µL mgsulfur −1) under high sulfur loadings (3.46 mg cm−2 and 3.73 mg cm−2), the cell still presents high reversible discharge capacities 679 and 762 mAh g−1 after 70 cycles, respectively. Further, at sulfur loadings up to 8.26 and 5.2 mg cm−2, the cells assembled with the bi-layers sulfur cathode and the tri-layers sulfur cathode give reversible capacities of 3.3 mAh cm−2 after the 100th cycle and 3.0 mAh cm−2 after the 120th cycle, respectively. This research not only demonstrates that the Fe-MoSe2@rGO functional plane is successfully designed and applied in Li-S batteries with superior electrochemical performances but also paves the novel way for developing a unique multi-layer cathode technique to enhance and advance the electrochemical behavior of Li-S cells at a high-sulfur-loading cathode under lean electrolyte/sulfur (E/S) ratio.

coredata.dc:title: Modulating of MoSe2 functional plane via doping-defect engineering strategy for the development of conductive and electrocatalytic mediators in Li-S batteries
